awd_titl_txt: Integrating Three-Dimensional Earthquake Rupture Dynamics, Ocean Acoustic Waves and Tsunami: Effects of Inelastic Failure in the Accretionary Wedge
awd_abstract_narration:
Shallow Subduction zones (upper 10 ? 15 km) host earthquakes on shallow-dipping plate interfaces and efficient in generating tsunami. The physics of tsunami generation from earthquake ruptures is, however, not well understood. This research will extend the researcher's previous earthquake rupture models to 3D and integrate these models with ocean acoustic waves and tsunami models. The fully coupled system of earthquake rupture and ocean acoustic waves and tsunamis provides the principal theoretical means for understanding the physics of these earthquakes and tsunami generation. These models can also be used extract useful signals that can be used in differentiating underlying mechanisms and tsunami early warning.

This proposal addresses one of the major unsolved problems in earthquake mechanics: the physics of anomalous rupture characteristics and tsunamigenesis in the shallow subduction zone. Why can these earthquakes generate tsunami efficiently but radiate weak high-frequency energy? What gives rise to slow rupture velocity and low moment-scaled radiated energy? Is tsunami generated by large shallow slip near the trench, distributed inelastic deformation in the wedge, or both? Can ocean acoustic waves be used in tsunami early warning? How does time-dependent seafloor deformation affect near-field tsunami? This 3-year research project will include the following activities: (i) Develop an updated Lagrangian finite-element approach to fully couple tsunami and ocean acoustic waves with earthquake rupture in 2D and 3D, and validate it with an existing Eulerian approach. (ii) Simulate along-strike rupture propagation with and without inelastic wedge failure and examine how they may significantly affect tsunami and ocean acoustic waves. Test and extract signals that can be used in tsunami early warning. (iii) Develop dynamic rupture models of representative tsunami earthquakes and simulate waveforms to regional/teleseismic distances. Examine the resolving power of teleseismic, high-rate GPS, and tsunami data.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI and students elucidated the physics of tsunamigenesis in the northern Japan Trench, Cascadia subduction zone, and sediment-rich margins in general. Elastic dislocation theory has been nearly universally used in the understanding of subduction zone earthquakes and tsunamigenesis. In order to explain large tsunamigenesis, elastic dislocation models require large shallow slip, which is probably best exemplified in modeling the 2011 M9 Tohoku earthquake. Nearly all the models used elastic dislocation theory and most models resolve large shallow slip (>50 m) near the trench updip from the hypocenter (~38.1°N), which seems consistent with the bathymetry data before and after the earthquake south of 38.5°N. However, there is a key observation that elastic dislocation models fail to explain, that is, the largest tsunami (with runup up to 40 m) occurred along the Sanriku coast more than 100 km north of the large shallow slip region at ~38.1°N. In order to explain the large tsunami along the Sanriku coast some elastic dislocation models require slip >30 m north of 39°N, which is, however, ruled out by the recent differential bathymetry data north of 39°N.

 

These important observations in the 2011 Tohoku earthquake indicate that elastic dislocation models are inadequate to explain the devastating tsunami in 2011. One mechanical inconsistency in elastic dislocation models is that dynamic stresses due to earthquake rupture may be large enough to cause inelastic deformation in the shallow narrow overriding wedge above the plate interface, especially when weak thick sediments are present. It is well recognized that large shallow slip on a shallow dipping fault (<10° in typical subduction zones) produces mostly horizontal displacement. Although horizontal displacement can generate tsunami at seafloor slopes this contribution can be inefficient because of typical gentle seafloor slopes at long wavelengths. Inelastic wedge deformation, however, generates seafloor uplift more efficiently than elastic dislocation due to frictional sliding on micro-fractures with steeper dips while diminishing slip on the fault, as was shown by the PI’s previous work in 2D. Inelastic deformation can also explain slow rupture propagation, deficient high-frequency seismic radiation, and low moment-scaled radiated energy due to plastic dissipation of energy in the wedge, as anomalously observed for tsunami earthquakes in the last 50 years.

 

In this project, by extending the previous 2D inelastic wedge deformation model to 3D and considering along-arc variation of sediment thickness in Japan Trench we showed that inelastic wedge deformation due to the sediment thickness variation is able to explain the puzzling large tsunami along the Sanriku coast in 2011, although the model was for a M8 earthquake (similar to the 1896 Sanriku earthquake). The inelastic failure of rich wedge sediments generate tsunami efficiently without large shallow slip, consistent with the bathymetry data in the northern Japan Trench. We also showed that the short-wavelength of inelastic uplift is instrumental in producing impulsive tsunami as observed offshore the Sanriku coast in 2011 (the impulsive signal was not observed in the south). Importantly, the impulsive tsunami can be greatly amplified by the rugged Sanriku coast to cause large runup. Our inelastic wedge deformation model can explain the observed large runup of the 1896 Sanriku tsunami without any model tuning. The inelastic deformation mechanism we showed seems the only mechanism to our knowledge that can explain all the key observations in the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami. A M9 model for the 2011 Tohoku earthquake incorporating this mechanism remains to be done.

We also extended the inelastic wedge deformation model to the Cascadia subduction zone. By fully coupling dynamic rupture, ocean acoustic waves, and tsunami we showed that inelastic wedge deformation of thick sediments in this large accretionary margin can produce tsunami at least twice as large as in elastic dislocation models. At the same time, inelastic wedge deformation reduces excitation of ocean acoustic waves, posing challenges in tsunami early warning by using these waves. Inelastic wedge deformation needs to be incorporated in future tsunami hazard assessments in this important margin.

 

Finally, we carried out a 3D fully-coupled model of dynamic rupture with off-fault plasticity, ocean acoustic waves, and tsunami in a strike-slip setting, such as the 2018 Palu earthquake. It is puzzling why a strike-slip earthquake produced a devastating tsunami that killed ~1200 people in Palu Bay, because a strike-slip earthquake is expected to generate mostly horizontal and little vertical motion. We showed that inelastic off-fault deformation at restraining bends under a shallow bay can produce efficient and more localized seafloor uplift than elastic dislocation models, which is more consistent with the observations in Palu Bay. Off-shore strike-slip faults with geometric complexities are widespread around the world, which are, however, largely ignored in current tsunami hazard assessments.

 

Overall, our work in this project provided a better physical understanding of tsunamigenesis that can be applied in evaluating and reducing tsunami hazard in different tectonic settings worldwide.
